{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3425103,"name":"","username":"Bruno","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-19T01:48:29.102Z","cooked":"

This is something I really want to do. Even more so using sensors and computer vision together. For example: when the robot manages to align with the april tag of a target or objective of the match, the control will vibrate indicating that the robot is aligned. Or the controller will vibrate when the game piece is completely inside the robot. Applications like this, mainly to “facilitate” communication between pilots.

GenericHID (from which XboxController and PS4Controller extend) has a setRumble method:

github.wpilib.org

GenericHID (WPILib API 2024.3.2)

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.wpilibj, class: GenericHID

On the XBox controller the left/right rumble types correspond to the low/high frequency rumble motors

We have our haptic feedback wrapped up in a class that allows us to difference rumble patterns (short, long, double etc). You can see our code here if you are interested.

Other points we have found are:

  • We always use both rumbles together. On our controllers the difference between them is minimal. We find the smaller one starts faster and the bigger one is easier to feel, so in combination they given faster, more definite feedback.
  • A very short rumble can be missed by the driver, particularly in the heat of a match. Mainly due to the time to spin up the rumble motor I think.
  • Patterns have to be very different to be properly registered in the heat of a match. We often have an ‘aim’ button that turns the robot to the target and has two possible feedback rumbles. One is failure (‘I can’t see the target’) and the other is success (‘I’ve turned to face the target’). If they are too similar it creates a lot of confusion and an angry drive team!
  • We always send the feedback to both the driver and operator controllers. We found it causes confusion if we don’t.
  • To quickly feel the rumble you can click on the rumble indicators in the Driver Station.
